This has taught me that you REALLY get what you pay for when it comes to networking equipment, but it also is a valuable adjunct to @SwiftOnSecurity's "it's always the LAN cable" - because sometimes it's not the LAN cable, it's the switch;)

Both of my ageing Zyxel GS1900-24HP switches got fried in a load-shedding electricity surge on Monday. Replaced it with a Ubiquiti ES48-750 edge switch I can't believe what a difference it's made to the network - no more slight lag on security cameras, everything is just perfect.

@lukechilds @MrHodl Ah I see what you‚Äôre saying; it would only be ineffectual if that local ElectrumX was firewalled and didn‚Äôt allow connections from the Internet. It‚Äôs still a non-target, though, as ElectrumX / bitcoind aren‚Äôt designed to satisfy transaction unlinkability.
@lukechilds @MrHodl An analog to this attack would be observing Electrum / ElectrumX, not observing bitcoind, since Electrum maintains its own separate database.

@lukechilds @MrHodl A Bitcoin + ElectrumX setup would be much, much worse in the event of a malicious ElectrumX server, as everything is openly exposed. I haven‚Äôt looked at comms between Bitcoin and ElectrumX, but if they‚Äôre not encrypted then it‚Äôs similarly much worse for a passive analysis attack.

@lukechilds @MrHodl The wallet fetches ALL the transactions from the daemon, and then checks to see if any are meant for that wallet. It does more stuff with outputs for that wallet than outputs that aren‚Äôt (which it can throw away), and so this attack is observing that.
@Emperor_YZ How do you verify that? I can also estimate Monero‚Äôs daily transaction volume, but just like cash it‚Äôs unverifiable.

@lukechilds @MrHodl The standard way of operating is to run the wallet and the daemon on the same computer, generally under the assumption that you‚Äôd have to attack the decrypted in-memory wallet to reveal anything sensitive. This attack observes lock contentions on that local daemon to leak data.
@Emperor_YZ Cash. Not fiat.

@lukechilds @MrHodl ie. they‚Äôre observing the change in lock patterns / comms patterns that happens when you interact with the node. A Monero node simply does not have the ability to scan for transactions at all - the code doesn‚Äôt pull in any wallet / scanning functionality:\nhttps://t.co/rIZxWwH0Q2

@lukechilds @MrHodl ‚ÄúIf a user connects their Monero wallet to a remote node,the required leakage in communication patterns & timing is observable by a malicious (yet passive) remote node provider,or by a passive network adversary that monitors the encrypted traffic between a wallet & trusted node‚Äù
@Emperor_YZ Can you tell how much cash is transacted daily? Would you describe cash as being ‚Äúless useful than [you] thought‚Äù? Anti-privacy idiots like you are beyond redemption.

@MrHodl @lukechilds Could be; Monero isn‚Äôt based on Bitcoin‚Äôs code, so it didn‚Äôt inherit that particularly bad design decision. It has had a separate daemon / wallet architecture from the outset. Unpack a release & you will notice there are monerod, monero-wallet-cli, & monero-wallet-rpc binaries.

@MrHodl He‚Äôs confused, wallet functionality isn‚Äôt built into Monero. It does support you using your own node remotely, which is what this exploit deals with (eg. You are tricked into using a malicious node instead of one under your control).

@Emperor_YZ I can‚Äôt tell if you‚Äôre being sarcastic or serious...on the off-chance you‚Äôre THAT stupid, Monero has no transactional volume because it‚Äôs private, so you can‚Äôt tell how much is being transacted on any timescale.
